message_1: Consider a graph with 6 vertices. How many ways can you color the vertices of this graph using 3 colors such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the chromatic polynomial. The chromatic polynomial P(G, k) of a graph G is a polynomial in the variable k that counts the number of proper k-colorings of G (i.e., colorings of the vertices of G in such a way that no two adjacent vertices have the same color).

However, since the problem does not specify any particular graph structure, we will consider the complete graph with 6 vertices (K6), as it has the most constraints on coloring.

The chromatic polynomial for a complete graph K_n is given by the formula:

P(K_n, k) = k(k-1)^{n-1} - (n-1)k(k-1)^{n-2}(k-2)

In our case, n = 6 and k = 3. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

P(K_6, 3) = 3(3-1)^{6-1} - (6-1)3(3-1)^{6-2}(3-2)
P(K_6, 3) = 3(2)^5 - 5*3(2)^4*1
P(K_6, 3) = 96 - 240
P(K_6, 3) = -144

However, the result is negative, which means that it is not possible to properly color a complete graph with 6 vertices using only 3 colors without having two adjacent vertices with the same color.

If the graph is not complete, the number of ways to color the vertices will depend on the specific structure of the graph.
